repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
<!--
  Thank you for contributing to Neovim!
  If this is your first time, check out https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests-prs
  for our PR guidelines.
-->

comment_data.body:
Does this do anything?
orig_cmd and cmd_start should equal when `has_visual_range` is true.

memcpy should suffice here but wasn't sure if it should `NUL` terminate. Thought a test would crash due to early termination.
Maybe porting a Vim test to Lua screen would crash?
This doesn't use Ex mode, which defeats the purpose of this test.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -259,6 +259,31 @@ func Test_ex_mode_errors()
   quit
 endfunc
 
+func Test_ex_mode_with_global()
+  CheckNotGui
+  CheckFeature timers
+
+  " This will get stuck in Normal mode after the failed "J", use a timer to
+  " get going again.
+  let lines =<< trim END
+    " call ch_logfile('logfile', 'w')
+    pedit
+    func FeedQ(id)
+      call feedkeys('Q', 't')
+    endfunc
+    call timer_start(10, 'FeedQ')
+    g/^/vi|HJ
+    call writefile(['done'], 'Xdidexmode')
+    qall!
+  END
+  call writefile(lines, 'Xexmodescript')
+  call assert_equal(1, RunVim([], [], '--clean -S Xexmodescript'))

comment_data.body: When testing manually it seems to work if I change `Q` to `gQ` and add `--headless -e -s`, but it somehow still doesn't work in the test...

comment_data.body: I don't think `S_LEN()` can be used here. It may fail to compile on platforms where  string.h defines `memmove()` as a macro instead of a function.

Oh, there is a problem that Nvim exits on input EOF during a non-blocking wait. With a small change to `input_get()` the following passes the test:
```diff
diff --git a/src/nvim/os/input.c b/src/nvim/os/input.c
index 0443f0ef12..6436991aa8 100644
--- a/src/nvim/os/input.c
+++ b/src/nvim/os/input.c
@@ -172,7 +172,7 @@ int input_get(uint8_t *buf, int maxlen, int ms, int tb_change_cnt, MultiQueue *e
     return push_event_key(buf, maxlen);
   }
 
-  if (result == kNone) {
+  if (result == kNone && ms != 0) {
     read_error_exit();
   }
 
diff --git a/test/old/testdir/test_ex_mode.vim b/test/old/testdir/test_ex_mode.vim
index 9a4a78e546..123109969a 100644
--- a/test/old/testdir/test_ex_mode.vim
+++ b/test/old/testdir/test_ex_mode.vim
@@ -269,15 +269,15 @@ func Test_ex_mode_with_global()
     " call ch_logfile('logfile', 'w')
     pedit
     func FeedQ(id)
-      call feedkeys('Q', 't')
+      call feedkeys('gQ', 't')
     endfunc
-    call timer_start(10, 'FeedQ')
+    call timer_start(0, 'FeedQ')
     g/^/vi|HJ
     call writefile(['done'], 'Xdidexmode')
     qall!
   END
   call writefile(lines, 'Xexmodescript')
-  call assert_equal(1, RunVim([], [], '--clean -S Xexmodescript'))
+  call assert_equal(1, RunVim([], [], '-e -s -S Xexmodescript'))
   call assert_equal(['done'], readfile('Xdidexmode'))
 
   call delete('Xdidexmode')
```
The timeout needs to be 0 instead of 10, as otherwise Nvim will do a blocking wait, which will exit due to EOF.

Do we need similar changes for `nvim_parse_cmd` ?

- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34398
